intro: Daucus nebrodensis, commonly known as the Sicilian carrot or the Nebrodian carrot, is a wild flowering plant native to the island of Sicily. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots, parsley, and dill, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or calcareous soils and is often found in open, sunny areas. Its flowers are small and clustered in umbels, a common feature among members of its family. Daucus nebrodensis is of interest to botanists due to its unique ecological adaptations and limited distribution.
